intro: Cephalorrhynchus takhtadzhianii, commonly known as the Armenian bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Armenia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers sunny to partially shaded environments. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and vulnerable species.
